body: Nearly four years after receiving about $50 million in Federal money to make life easier for pedestrians in New York City, officials with the city's Department of Transportation acknowledge that they have made little headway in achieving that goal. And unless they use the money by a deadline that is less than a year away, the city may have to give
title: New York City Slow to Help Its Pedestrians

body: Sheila Dean will not say, not out loud, why Thanksgiving is so special this year. She will hint at the reason, whisper about it. For Anthony Dean, the man she lives with and plans to marry and whose name she has already taken, there will be no Thanksgiving next year, the doctors say. Mr. Dean is dying of cancer. With luck, he will see Christmas,
title: A Meal With Family Alleviates the Burden For a Dying Man

body: TROUBLE not of their making has made partners of Carlton Collier and Martin Horwitz, one from the nonprofit world, the other a private owner. They are working together on a rehabilitation project in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn that illustrates the new ties forming between the nonprofit and for-profit sectors as public subsidies for
title: The Growing Nonprofit Partnership With For-Profits

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. title: Residential Resales

body: THREE years ago, Alan Marks, a Park Slope real-estate agent, would watch a one-bedroom apartment on Sackett Street, in an area known as the Lower Slope, languish on his list of rentals for longer than a month. Prospective tenants would take one look at the block, dotted with abandoned buildings and a few scraggly trees, turn up their noses and keep
title: The Boom in Park Slope

body: In a city where traffic lights and stop signs often do little to control the flow of traffic, a less costly deterrent is being given a chance to show whether it can keep drivers from speeding through congested neighborhoods. New York City, prepare for the ''speed hump.'' A hump, not to be confused, traffic engineers say, with the noisier speed
title: Listen: No Thump. Speed Humps Are Lower. Also Quieter, Kinder and Gentler.

body: There's a prairie growing on a triangle of concrete in Brooklyn. It's called the Gateway Triangle, because it's a gateway to both Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, and because it's a triangle formed by Fulton Street and Vanderbilt and Gates Avenues. It's where three bus lines stop. In fact, the fumes are so noxious, gardeners were advised not to grow
title: CUTTINGS;An Unlikely Prairie Thrives in Brooklyn

body: Friday nights at the Brooklyn Moon Cafe are vaguely reminiscent of an earlier era: Fingers snap, fists are raised in tribute to the spoken word, a few in the crowd sport sunglasses. But the owner, Michael Thompson, said he began the now-trendy Friday-night open-mike sessions not as a haven for revolutionary pauper-poets but as a moneymaker. "I
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE;Of Latte and the Literati: A Renaissance of Readings

body: WHEN his ceiling collapsed with a thunderous crash during a recent dinner party, John Woodrow Kelley, a classical painter, claims he was undaunted. "That's what you get for living in an old brownstone," he said with a grin. Order has since been restored to his small floor-through apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, where a welcoming calm prevails.
title: HOUSE PROUD;Beyond the Grecian Formula: Grandeur on a Small Scale

body: AFTER shopping for a house almost every day for a year, Genevieve Wilkins found just the thing in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn -- a three-family brick and frame house on Claremont Avenue that a bank was selling out of foreclosure for $145,000. But she had a problem. She had saved enough for the down payment, but not enough to manage the
title: Giving Home Buying a Lift in Urban Neighborhoods
